newsitem.title: CANADA: Liberals, Bloc neck and neck in Quebec - poll.
newsitem.headline: Liberals, Bloc neck and neck in Quebec - poll.

text.p: A new poll released on Thursday shows the ruling Liberals and separatist Bloc Quebecois tied in Quebec ahead of the June 2 federal election.

The poll, published by the French-language Montreal newspaper La Presse, showed the Liberals and Bloc each at 39 percent, with the Conservatives at 13 percent after the redistribution of undecided respondents.
The survey by the polling firm SOM was conducted May 2-7. It sampled 980 people, with a margin of error of 3.63 percent, 19 times out of 20.
The poll showed a four point gain for the Liberals and one point drop for the Bloc since the last SOM poll in mid-April, before the election call.
Among French-speaking voters, the Bloc led the Liberals 49 percent to 33 percent. "The linguistic polarization should in principle ensure a majority of seats to the Bloc," the paper said.
The poll also showed Conservative leader Jean Charest trusted by 59 percent of Quebecers, with 41 percent trusting Liberal Prime Minister Jean Chretien and 39 percent Bloc leader Gilles Duceppe.
In the 1993 election, the Bloc won 54 of Quebec's 75 seats, followed by the Liberals with 20 seats and one independent.
